metadata.title: International Master Supply Agreement (Electronics Components)
metadata.tariff_adjustment_policy: Section 9 Tariff Adjustment formula; threshold 3%; annual cap 8% per product family. Buyer pays import duties (Section 8).
metadata.baseline_duty_and_hs_reference: Schedule A lists HS codes and baseline US duty rates for Chinese-origin goods.

queries.question: Compute our net exposure if the US raises Section 301 tariffs on HS 8538.90 from 25% to 35% effective next month. We have an undelivered PO for 12,000 units of AR-PCB-X1 with a CIF customs value of $50 per unit. Apply the contract’s tariff adjustment, thresholds and caps. Who pays what and can we cancel?

answer.summary: Buyer pays the new 35% duty at import and owes a price increase to Seller equal to the 10% duty delta × customs value, subject to the 3% threshold and 8% annual cap; cancellation of undelivered POs is allowed if no agreement in 30 days.
assumptions: Customs value equals CIF $50 as stated.
Current year cap headroom > 8% not exceeded.

queries.question: If the US reduces tariffs on HS 8542.31 from 25% to 10% for Chinese origin, what price change applies to AR-IC-M4 for undelivered quantities with CIF $30/unit? Estimate the decrease and state who benefits.

answer.summary: Price decreases by the 15% duty delta × customs value for undelivered units; Buyer still pays the reduced 10% duty at import.

queries.question: Identify all HS codes and baseline US duty rates from the Agreement for analytics.

answer.summary: HS 8538.90 (25%), HS 8542.31 (25%), HS 7616.99 (10%) for Chinese-origin products.

queries.question: Does the 3% de minimis threshold in Section 9 block an adjustment if tariffs on HS 7616.99 increase from 10% to 12% with CIF $7.20/unit?

answer.summary: Yes. The landed-cost delta is 2% (12% − 10%), below the 3% threshold; no adjustment applies.

queries.question: We already applied 6% worth of tariff adjustments this year on AR-IC-M4. A new increase would imply a further 4% price rise. What cap applies and how much of the new increase is billable under Section 9.3?

answer.summary: Annual cap is 8% per product family; only 2% additional is billable, 2% is blocked by the cap.

queries.question: Who is the Importer-of-Record and which documents must accompany each shipment to support customs classification and origin?

answer.summary: Buyer is Importer-of-Record; Seller provides commercial invoice, packing list and certificate of origin (if available).

queries.question: If the parties cannot agree on a tariff adjustment within 30 days after a change in law, what cancellation rights does Buyer have?

answer.summary: Buyer may cancel undelivered POs for the affected Products without penalty.

queries.question: Summarize the net tariff exposure profile of this Agreement by Incoterm and role assignment.

answer.summary: FOB Shanghai with Buyer as IOR: Buyer bears import duties. Section 9 can shift economic burden via price adjustments (±) subject to a 3% threshold and 8% cap; Buyer can cancel if no agreement.

metadata.title: EMEA Distribution Agreement (Medical Devices)
metadata.tariff_adjustment_policy: Section 7: repricing if composite duty increase ≥8% for 3 consecutive months; else forecast reduction up to 30% or termination of line; Section 6: Distributor bears duties, tariffs and VAT.
metadata.baseline_duty_and_hs_reference: Schedule A lists HS codes and baseline EU duty rates for US-origin products.

queries.question: EU imposes a retaliatory tariff that raises the composite duty on HS 9026.20 by +9% for three consecutive months. What remedies are available and who bears the duty?

answer.summary: Distributor bears the duty as IOR. After ≥8% composite increase for 3 months, either party may request repricing; failing agreement in 30 days, Distributor may cut its 12-month forecast by up to 30% or Supplier may terminate the affected line.

queries.question: If composite duty rises by 6% for two months and then reverts, does the repricing trigger?

answer.summary: No. The trigger requires ≥8% increase sustained for three consecutive months.

queries.question: Calculate landed-cost impact if baseline EU duty on HS 8544.42 is 3.5% and a temporary safeguard adds +5% for three months. Distributor imports €200,000 of NMD-CABLE-EU per month. State exposure and available actions.

answer.summary: Composite increase = 5%. Monthly incremental duty ≈ €10,000 (5% × 200,000). Trigger not met (needs ≥8% × 3 months); no repricing right, but normal purchasing discretion applies.

queries.question: List the HS codes and baseline EU duty rates for all Products.
Who is Importer-of-Record and what Incoterm allocates export/import formalities?

answer.summary: Distributor is IOR; EXW Boston places export and import formalities and risk on Distributor after pickup.

queries.question: If repricing is requested and no agreement is reached in 30 days, can Supplier unilaterally change prices?

answer.summary: No unilateral price change is stated; instead, Distributor may reduce forecast up to 30% or Supplier may terminate the affected Product line with 60 days’ notice.

queries.question: Assume €1.2M monthly imports of NMD-SENS-45; composite duty increases by 9% for three months. Estimate total incremental duty and outline remedies.

answer.summary: Incremental duty ~ €108,000 per month (9% × 1.2M), total €324,000 over 3 months. Remedies: request repricing; if no agreement, Distributor may cut forecast by 30% or Supplier may terminate the line.

queries.question: Summarize tariff exposure profile under this Agreement.

answer.summary: EXW/IOR Distributor: Distributor bears tariffs and VAT. Economic relief via repricing only if composite duty rises ≥8% for 3 months; otherwise demand/flexibility tools (forecast reduction or termination) manage exposure.

metadata.title: Purchase Agreement (Solar Glass) - CIF India
metadata.tariff_adjustment_policy: Section 6: Buyer bears anti-dumping/safeguard duties; repricing/cancellation if composite duty increases >12% above Baseline Composite Duty in Schedule A.
metadata.baseline_duty_and_hs_reference: Schedule A contains HS 7007.19 items with baseline composite duty 10-12%.

queries.question: India imposes an anti-dumping duty of 15% on HS 7007.19, raising composite duty from the 10% Baseline Composite Duty to 25%. For an undelivered order of 20,000 m² of GLT-SG-3.2 at CIF $8.10/m², compute Buyer’s incremental duty and whether repricing/cancellation rights apply.

answer.summary: Incremental duty = 15% × $8.10 × 20,000 = $24,300. The composite increase (>12% over baseline) triggers Section 6.2; Buyer may request repricing or cancel open POs for the affected Products with 15 days’ notice.

queries.question: If composite duty increases from 12% to 20% for GLT-ARC-3.2, does the trigger fire and what are the options?

answer.summary: Increase vs Baseline Composite Duty (12%) is +8%. Trigger requires >12% increase, so it does NOT fire; no contract repricing/cancellation right under Section 6.2.

queries.question: Who is Importer-of-Record and what Incoterm allocates risk transfer in this Agreement?

answer.summary: Buyer is Importer-of-Record and pays Indian duties; CIF Nhava Sheva: risk transfers to Buyer upon discharge at port.

queries.question: Provide HS code mapping and Baseline Composite Duty for analytics.

answer.summary: All items are HS 7007.19, PRC origin; Baseline Composite Duty is 10% for GLT-SG-3.2 and 4.0, 12% for GLT-ARC-3.2.

queries.question: If anti-dumping adds +14% on GLT-SG-4.0, compute incremental duty for 12,500 m² at CIF $9.20/m² and state whether the trigger is met.

answer.summary: Incremental duty = 14% × $9.20 × 12,500 = $16,100. Trigger vs 10% Baseline is +14% (>12%), so repricing/cancellation rights apply.

queries.question: Can Buyer refuse to pay anti-dumping duty under this Agreement?

answer.summary: No. Section 5.1 places responsibility for Basic Customs Duty, safeguard/anti-dumping duty and IGST on Buyer as IOR.

queries.question: If Buyer requests repricing, what is the adjustment formula?

answer.summary: Adjustment equals the incremental duty multiplied by the applicable Customs Value for undelivered quantities.

queries.question: Summarize tariff exposure profile for this Agreement.

answer.summary: CIF India with Buyer as IOR: Buyer bears import duties and anti-dumping. Economic relief is available only when composite duty increases by >12% vs Baseline; Buyer may request repricing or cancel open POs.

metadata.title: UK Framework Procurement Agreement (Packaged Foods)
metadata.tariff_adjustment_policy: Section 6: Seller may request price increase if new UK tariffs raise landed cost by >5% vs Baseline Duty; Buyer may reject increases >6% in rolling 12 months and cancel; decreases must be passed through.
metadata.baseline_duty_and_hs_reference: Schedule A lists HS codes and baseline UK duty (0%) for ES-origin foods.

queries.question: UK introduces a 7% tariff on HS 1509.10 (olive oil) where Baseline UK Duty is 0%. For a call-off of 40,000 L at a DDP unit price of £5.60, what price increase can Seller request and can Buyer refuse?

answer.summary: Seller’s landed cost increase is 7% of Customs Value. Section 6.1 permits passing through the incremental duty since >5%. However, Buyer may reject increases exceeding 6% in a rolling 12 months and cancel undelivered orders.
answer.who_bears_tariff: Seller (IOR under DDP) initially; economic pass-through per contract limits.

queries.question: If tariffs drop from 7% back to 0% on HS 1902.19, what happens to pricing?

answer.summary: Any decrease must be passed through to Buyer effective on the implementation date.

queries.question: List HS codes, origin and Baseline UK Duty for all Products.

answer.summary: HS 1902.19 (0%), 2103.20 (0%), 1509.10 (0%), origin ES; Incoterm DDP; IOR Seller.

queries.question: Who is Importer-of-Record and what are the implications for tariff exposure?

answer.summary: Seller is IOR under DDP; Seller pays duties and handles customs. Economic exposure can be passed through only if landed cost increases >5%, and Buyer can cap effective increases at 6% with cancellation option.

queries.question: Assume the UK imposes 4% on HS 2103.20 and 3% on HS 1902.19. Can Seller increase prices under Section 6.1?

answer.summary: No. The landed cost increases (3-4%) are below the >5% threshold; no price increase right under Section 6.1.

queries.question: If Seller proposes an 8% price increase due to tariffs across the portfolio within 12 months, what recourse does Buyer have?

answer.summary: Buyer may reject increases exceeding 6% in a rolling 12-month period and cancel undelivered orders for affected Products.

queries.question: Explain how rules of origin affect duty liability under this Agreement.

answer.summary: Seller must maintain origin documentation to qualify for preferential duty under the EU-UK TCA; if origin changes and duty applies, Seller remains responsible for resulting duties.

queries.question: Summarize tariff exposure profile of this Framework.

answer.summary: DDP/IOR Seller: Seller bears tariff and VAT liability, with limited pass-through if >5%. Buyer can cap increases at 6% and cancel; decreases must be passed through.

metadata.title: Equipment Purchase Agreement (Industrial Sewing Lines)
metadata.tariff_adjustment_policy: Section 6: Seller may pass through incremental US tariffs on EU-origin equipment; annual pass-through cap 5% of total contract; evidence required. Section 5: Seller pays duties as IOR.
metadata.baseline_duty_and_hs_reference: Schedule A includes HS 8452.10 and 8537.10 with baseline US duty ~2.5-2.7%.

queries.question: The US adds a 10% tariff on EU-origin sewing machines (HS 8452.10) and a 5% surcharge on control cabinets (HS 8537.10). Compute the maximum pass-through Seller can invoice this year if the total contract price is $478,000 and neither line has shipped.

answer.summary: Pass-through equals incremental duty on Customs Value but is capped at 5% of total contract price per Section 6.2. With a $478,000 contract, the cap is $23,900. Seller cannot pass through more than $23,900 this year even if calculated incremental duties exceed that amount.

calculations.note: Exact incremental duty requires Customs Values per line; cap governs the maximum invoiceable amount.

answer.who_bears_tariff: Seller pays at import as IOR, then may pass through incrementally within cap.

queries.question: If baseline duty on HS 8452.10 is 2.5% and a new 8% tariff is introduced (total 10.5%), compute the incremental pass-through on Line-A if the Customs Value equals the line price ($420,000).

answer.summary: Incremental rate = 8%. Pass-through = 8% × $420,000 = $33,600, subject to the 5% annual cap across the contract.

queries.question: What evidence must Seller provide to support any pass-through invoice?

answer.summary: Documentary evidence such as entry summaries supporting the claimed incremental duty.

queries.question: Identify HS codes and baseline US duty rates from Schedule A.
Who is Importer-of-Record and what Incoterm is used? Summarize the exposure.

answer.summary: Seller is IOR under DDP New York; Seller pays duties and tariffs, then may pass through incremental tariffs within a 5% annual cap.

queries.question: If only Line-B ships this year at $58,000 customs value and a 5% tariff applies, can Seller pass through the full $2,900 even though the cap is $23,900?

answer.summary: Yes. The cap is an upper bound; a $2,900 pass-through is below the $23,900 annual cap.

queries.question: If the United States rescinds the 10% tariff mid-year after Seller invoiced a pass-through for Line-A, does the Agreement require rebates?

answer.summary: No explicit rebate obligation is stated; Section 6 provides for pass-through of incremental duties with evidence, but does not specify claw-backs upon tariff decreases. Parties may agree commercially.

queries.question: Summarize tariff exposure profile of the Agreement.

answer.summary: DDP/IOR Seller with pass-through right for incremental US tariffs on EU-origin equipment, capped at 5% of total contract per year; evidence required.
